item.title: Elisa Galliano
item.description:
So, we did a thing‚Ä¶ The first preprint from the lab is finally out üìúü•≥
If you fancy dopamine, and weird axonless cells, and electrophysiology, and poking around different brain areas, you should have a look‚§µÔ∏è

item.title: Ben Zimmer
item.description: The rebranding of Twitter as X reflects Elon Musk's longtime obsession with the 24th letter. But he's hardly the first person to find intrigue and mystery in the letter X. My latest for WSJ. https://on.wsj.com/45xKcKw

item.description: A spider just crawled into my keyboard.It's okay, I have it under Ctrl.

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Regional, circuit and network heterogeneity of brain abnormalities in psychiatric disorders
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01404-6
#neuroscience

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: I've been asked a couple questions a lot in reaction to my story on how our species might have gone extinct before we started. [Gift link: https://tinyurl.com/bddpxjk9 ] 1/3

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: 1. Isn't this just the Toba eruption? No--that was 70,000 years ago, not 930,000 years ago. And it's clear now that Toba did NOT bottleneck our species. https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25967

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: 2. What does this have to do with our chromosomes? We have 23 pairs of chromosomes, while apes have 24. That's because two of our chromosomes fused in the past. This 2022 study estimates the fusion happened between 400,000 and 1.5 million years ago. The proposed bottleneck falls right in the middle of that range--suggesting it might have had a role. https://bmcgenomics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12864-022-08828-7

item.title: FocalPlane
item.description:
This #FluorescenceFriday is an exciting one for us, as we announce the winner of our 2023 image competition! After all the votes have been counted, the winner is Rebecca Simkin
with her image of neuromuscular junctions. Find out more about Rebecca & her research:
https://focalplane.biologists.com/2023/09/01/and-the-winner-is/Thanks to everyone who voted. We had so many fantastic entries for the competition, and we will be featuring many of the researchers in our 'Featured image' posts over the coming weeks.
https://focalplane.biologists.com/?s=Featured+image

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
#ComplexityThoughts is back after the summer break! In the issue #14 amazing new papers, from #NetworkScience foundations to #OriginOfLife #Neuroscience and #ComputationalSocialScienceUnraveling complexity: building knowledge, one paper at a time!
Not yet subscribed? It's never too late, and it's 100% free.https://manlius.substack.com/p/complexity-thoughts-issue-14

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: Have you read "The B Lane Swimmer?". If not, you're in for a treat: https://holly.witteman.ca/the-b-lane-swimmer/

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
If this resonates with you, maybe fast-forward?
People with panic disorder wait an average of ten years before discussing their symptoms with a doctor, psychologist, or other professional (including an acupuncturist or ‚Äúspiritual advisor‚Äù). Those with social phobia delay sixteen years; those with generalized anxiety disorder, nine years. With specific phobia, the wait is twenty years.
https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/240941/on-edge-by-andrea-petersen/

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
Provocative
As a young psychologist, this chills me to my bones. Apparently is possible to reach the stratosphere of scientific achievement, to publish over and over again in ‚Äúhigh impact‚Äù journals, to rack up tens of thousands of citations, and for none of it to matter. Every marker of success, the things that are supposed to tell you that you're on the right track, that you're making a real contribution to science‚Äîthey might mean nothing.
(I agree: time to rethink the idea that any individual is how this works).I‚Äôm so sorry for psychology‚Äôs loss, whatever it ishttps://www.experimental-history.com/p/im-so-sorry-for-psychologys-loss

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
Now one of the problems of the #neuroscience community is that we're all split among multiple platforms. Really too bad.
And I really mean it. Aside from graduate school, from 2019 to 2022 was probably the time that I learned the most about the brain because of the vast amount of material shared on social media. It was great fun for some time. üòî

item.title: Erik Uden ü¶£
item.description: A man in Saudi Arabia has been sentenced to death for his tweets, and surprise: Elon Musk is NOT funding his legal bill as promised because there's a good chance that the necessary data to identify this man came from the second largest shareholder of Twitter: the Saudi prince Alwaleed bin Talal. Musk has been awfully silent about this as you can't really make your ‚Äúfreedom of speech!!‚Äù argument when you assist with killing a retired teacher for the regime critic posts they made on your platform, only possible because that regime owns a huge chunk of ‚Äúyour‚Äù platform.

item.title: Theresa Desrochers
item.description: At some point on social media I saw a post about developing a publishing agreement with trainees who were leaving the lab. I thought it was a great idea, but now can't find where I saw it. Does anyone have a resource like that they would be willing to share or have something they could point me to?#academia #publishing

item.title: David Pfau
item.description: Thrilled to share what I‚Äôve been working on for the last two years - a new way to solve one of the most fundamental problems in quantum physics, computing excited states! https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16848

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: The things you find in closets at MIT. An old device that used electricity to make clinical lesions (controlled damage) in the human brain to treat disorders. There is a Shudder channel movie script in there somewhere.

item.title: Cat Hicks
item.description: I wrote about the idea of craft -- a concept I've been hearing a lot lately in conversations about software work and often find myself wrangling with. But it also turned out to be about my grandpa. In a year of many losses, I have been thinking a lot about those I love and try to take with me in everything I do. https://www.drcathicks.com/post/on-craft

item.title: It's The Weekend
